posts.cooked: I am going to be getting a camera myself very soon (Sony a6400 is what I have decided on) and I want to get at least one prime lens. Need help deciding a focal length that will work with robotics and more specifically photographing robots in matches from the media box.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: Not as familiar with mirrorless digital lens focal length equivalents. But Iâ€™ve got a 105mm f/2.8 for my Nikon DSLR (technically for macro) but it takes good photos at a distance. But you can always get a good 35mm to 50mm and crop later.  FRC events have lots of variation in lighting, so make sure its something with a good wide aperature.
105mm, thatâ€™s a lot more zoomed in than I wouldâ€™ve thought.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
This was taken with the 105mm from about 8ft away. Further away could get some good tight shots. DSC_0223small 1504Ã—1004 482 KB

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked:
So I have played around with a few cameras and lenses just by whats available when I am there.

My personal is a lower end - Canon Eos 4000D with a cheap 70-300mm (f4 - 5.6)  and a 24 -55mm (f4-5.6 I believe) Here are some examples from last year. (Unfortunately, my lens gear was stripped leading to some more blur. As well as not having it finely dialed in for 300mm f5.6 so some grain got introduced in post. (Hofstraâ€™s lighting setup wasnâ€™t ideal for lower-level equipment.)

IMG_3935 1920Ã—1280 336 KB

IMG_3935 1920Ã—1280 336 KB

IMG_3935 1920Ã—1280 336 KB

During CNY 19 I had my friends camera an E0s 6D with a 70-200 (f2.8)

IMG_9828 1920Ã—2880 343 KB At 75mm got this

IMG_9828 1920Ã—2880 343 KB

IMG_9828 1920Ã—2880 343 KB

And I know he would usually be hanging around up in the stands or from afar getting shots with the 70-200.

Each venue can vary with lighting, so It can be harder or easier to get cleaner shots. (Better lenses always help)

But itâ€™s also a matter of is it more for shooting robots from afar or up close

I plan to be close up in the media box for all of our matches, but from what Iâ€™m getting and what I can afford, Iâ€™m probably gonna get a 50mm f1.8 and because my camera Iâ€™m getting is a crop sensor, itâ€™s something like a 75mm equivalent.

posts.name: Duncan Macdonald
posts.cooked:
Are you familiar with the photo pills app or any other depth of field tables?

An FRC field is a known size and  the media box will be the same place it was last year (if youâ€™re going to the same event). If you map out the distances to the different interesting areas of the field, your robot is a known volume at those distances.

Judgeâ€™s seating (ideal) to community with your camera and a 50 prime will behave about like this.

posts.name: ricky
posts.cooked:
Skirting your direct question, do you really need a prime lens for what you want to do with your camera?

You said you want to photograph robots in matches, so Iâ€™d consider a sports photography-like approach to your methods ( 10 Sports Photography tips for beginners â€“ DigitalRev ) which prioritizes flexibility in finding shots (thus, suggesting the use of zoom/telephoto lenses). Legendary FIM photographer Daniel Ernst ( Daniel Ernst | Flickr ) uses zoom/telephoto lenses across all his photos Iâ€™ve seen.

link_counts.title: 10 Sports Photography tips for beginners â€“ DigitalRev

posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked: Iâ€™ve been shooting Sony and that sensor size for several years, and my routine now is I leave my 55-210 lens on for candid team & robot action shots from distance. And I take wide shots & closer in people shots with my iphone. I have prime lenses, including 35 autofocus and 50 & 85 manual focusâ€¦ beautiful images with bokeh and everything, but I find I always need to switch back to the zoom + itâ€™s a pain to drag the bag around, so I go with the approach I described.
Same here, I end up only using my prime lenses in the pits when Iâ€™m walking around taking detailed shots of robots and their internals.

Thankyou for all of your advice, I really appreciate it and it was very helpful. After talking to some photographers and other people and looking at reviews, I have decided on a tameron 17 - 70 f2.8. It does have some compromises and at full zoom, itâ€™s not the sharpest lens, but for me and what I do itâ€™s perfect and I can deal with the compromises. Any further advice on this thread is still appreciated and will be helpful for anyone else looking into the same thing so please keep giving advice below. Thanks again everyone.

posts.name: Wayne Doenges
posts.cooked: I have a Tamron 18-400mm super telephoto lens. I love it! I only have one camera (Nikon D7100) so I donâ€™t have to keep changing lenses for different distances. To get the shots, I run the ISO at 6400 with High noise setting on.
